title-group.article-title: Long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from the rhizomes of Iris domestica

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from the rhizomes of
Iris domestica

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Jiayuan Li, Gang Ni, Yanfei Liu, Renzhong Wang, Dequan Yu *

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: State Key Laboratory of Bioactive Substance and Function of Natural Medicines, Institute of Materia Medica, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, 100050, People’ s Republic of China

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Long-chain fatty acid derivatives Cytotoxicity
Antioxidation
ABSTRACT

Six undescribed long-chain fatty acid esters of isoflavone glycosides were obtained from the rhizomes of
Iris domestica
(L.). Their structures were elucidated by comprehensive spectroscopic data, alkaline hydrolysis, and acid hydrolysis. This is the first report of the long-chain (C 14 –C 18 ) fatty acid derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from natural products. Belamcandnoate B and D exhibited moderate cytotoxic activities against HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 1.69–6.86 μ M. Belamcandnoate B and E exhibited 72.27 and 58.98% inhibitory activities, respectively, against Fe 2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation at a concentration of 10 μ M.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
To date, chemical, enzymatic and chemoenzymatic acylation of flavonoids and dihydrochalcone with various acyl donors (C2–C18 chain length) has been reported (
, 2016;
; Ziaullah et al., 2013). However, there are no reports about long-chain (C 14 –C 18 ) fatty acid esters of isoflavone glycosides isolated from natural products. The rich isoflavones in
I. domestica
enable us to obtain the chain length of fatty acid derivatives of isoflavone glycosides from this plant. In the course of our ongoing search for structurally unique and biologically diverse metabolites, six undescribed long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavone glycosides ( Fig. 1 ) were isolated from the rhizomes of
I. domestica .
Acylation occurs at C-6 of glucoside, and the chain length of fatty acids as acyl donors is from C14 to C18. In addition, in an in vitro bioassay, the cytotoxic, antioxidative, and anti-inflammatory activities of the isolated compounds are evaluated. Here, we describe the isolation, structural elucidation, and bioactive evaluation of compounds 1–6 .

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Belamcandnoate A ( 1 ) was obtained as a pale yellow oil (MeOH). Its molecular formula, C 37 H 50 O 13 , was determined by the HRESIMS ion at [M + H] + m/z 703.33234 (calcd 703.33242), which indicated 13 indices of hydrogen deficiency. 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) also exhibited five hydroxyl groups at δ H 12.92 (1H, s, OH-5), 9.09 (1H, s, OH-3 ′ ), 5.57 (1H, d, J = 5.8 Hz, OH-2 ′′ ), 5.38 (1H, d, J = 6.4 Hz, OH-4 ′′ ), 5.31 (1H, m, OH-3 ′′ ), including two hydroxyl groups at the aromatic ring. A characteristic singlet at δ H 8.45 (1H, s, H-2) implies that 1 is an isoflavone. The aromatic signals at δ H 7.04 (1H, d, J = 2.3 Hz, H-2 ′ ) and 6.96 (2H, m, H-6 ′ , 5 ′ ) show the presence of an ABX aromatic system. An aromatic proton singlet at δ H 6.85 (1H, s, H-8) is observed, which suggest the presence of a trisubstituted aromatic ring A. Two methoxyl groups at δ H 3.79 (3H, s, OMe-4 ′ ) and 3.75 (3H, s, OMe-6) are assigned. The anomeric proton signal at 5.16 (1H, d, J = 8.8 Hz, H-1 ′′ ), an isolated methylene at δ H 4.29 (1H, dd, J = 14.5, 1.9 Hz, H-6 ′′ a), 4.09 (1H, dd, J = 14.5, 9.5 Hz, H-6 ′′ b), and four methines at δ H 3.75 (1H, m, H-5 ′′ ), 3.36 (1H, m, H-2 ′′ ), 3.31 (1H, m, H-3 ′′ ), 3.18 (1H, m, H-4 ′′ ) demonstrate the presence of a β -glucopyranosyl unit. These signals at δ H 0.84 (3H, t, J = 8.5 Hz, H-16 ′′′ ), 2.26 (2H, m, H-2 ′′′ ), and partially overlapping aliphatic protons at δ H 1.24–1.07 are characteristic of fatty acids. Based on the HSQC spectrum, the 13 C NMR data identified 37 resonances, which were categorized as a ketone carbonyl at δ C 180.7 (C-3); an ester carbonyl at δ C 172.8 (C-1 ′′′ ); seven oxygenated aromatic carbons at δ C 156.4 (C-7), 154.9 (C- 2), 153.0 (C-5), 152.4 (C-9), 146.2 (C-3 ′ ), 147.8 (C-4 ′ ), 132.5 (C-6); seven aromatic carbons at δ C 122.0 (C-3), 123.1 (C-1 ′ ), 119.7 (C-6 ′ ), 116.3 (C-2 ′ ), 111.9 (C-5 ′ ), 106.6 (C-10), 94.0 (C-8); a glucosyl group at δ C 99.7 (C-1 ′′ ), 76.4 (C-3 ′′ ), 73.8 (C-5 ′′ ), 73.0 (C-2 ′′ ), 70.1 (C-4 ′′ ), 63.4 (C- 6 ′′ ); as well as some partially overlapping aliphatic carbons at δ C 22.1–33.5. A detailed comparison of the spectroscopic data of 1 with those of the known isoflavone iristectorin A (
) indicates that compound 1 is a long-chain fatty acid acylated derivative of iristectorin A. The HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ) from OMe ( δ H 3.79) to C-4 ′ and from OMe ( δ H 3.75) to C-6, along with the NOESY correlations from OMe ( δ H 3.79) to H-5 ′ and from OMe ( δ H 3.75) to H-1 ′′ indicate that two methoxyl groups are located at C-4 ′ and C-6, respectively, which further confirms the presence of iristectorin A. The HMBC correlation from H-6 ′′ to C-1 ′′′ indicates that the acylated site is located on OH-6’’. Analysis of the unsaturation of 1 reveals that the long-chain fatty acid is saturated.

In an i n vitro bioassay, the cytotoxicities (against HCT-116, HepG2, BGC-823, A549, and MCF-7 five human cancer cell lines with paclitaxel as a positive control), antiinflammation (inhibitory effects against lipopolysaccharide-induced nitric oxide (NO) production on BV2 microglial cells), and antioxidation (Fe2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation) of the isolated compounds were evaluated. The cytotoxic activities showed that compound 2 exhibited moderate cytotoxic activities against the HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 6.80, 5.74, and 5.95 μ M ( Table 3 ). Compound 4 displayed moderated cytotoxic activities against the HCT-116, HepG2, and BGC823 cell lines with IC 50 values of 5.73, 6.86, and 1.69 μ M. Compounds 2 and 5 exhibited 72.27 and 58.98% inhibitory activities, respectively, against the Fe 2+ /cysteine-induced liver microsomal lipid peroxidation at a concentration of 10 μ M (curcumin as the positive control drug, 87.08%). The anti-inflammatory results displayed that they were inactive with IC 50 values > 10 μ M.

In addition, the brief structure and activity were discussed. Compounds 2 and 4 with the 5 ′ -OCH 3 group displayed significant cytotoxic activities, which suggested that the presence of 5 ′ -OCH 3 might be crucial for the cytotoxic activities. Moreover, OCH 3 at C-5 ′ in the saturated long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives of isoflavones might play an important role in antioxidant activities. However, there were too little data to conclude whether the length and the degree of unsaturation of the fatty acid side chain are equally important. More evidence should be supported in the future.
3. Conclusion

I. domestica
, a type of traditional Chinese medicine rich in isoflavones, is mainly used to treat sore throat. The diverse structures and inspired bioactivities of isoflavones from
I. domestica
make wider application prospects. In our research, six undescribed long-chain fatty acid acylated derivatives with very long chain unsaturated and saturated fatty acids (C14–C18) were obtained. This is the first report of long-chain fatty acid (C14–C18) ester derivatives of isoflavones from natural products. Our findings enrich the chemical and biological diversity of flavonoid glycosides, and provide a new research idea for compound modification.
4. Experimental
4.1. General experimental procedures

A JASCO P-2000 automatic digital polarimeter was used to record optical rotations. UV spectra were conducted on a JASCO V-650 spectrophotometer. A Nicolet 5700 spectrometer using an FT-IR microscope transmission method was used to obtain IR spectra. Bruker-600 spectrometer was employed to measure NMR spectra. HRESIMS data were measured on Dionex UltiMate 3000 UHPLC and Thermo Scientific Q Exactive Focus Mass Spectrometer. Analytical HPLC was performed on an Agilent 1260 infinity system equipped with a DAD-UV detector. Preparative HPLC was conducted on a CXTH system (Beijing Chuangxintongheng instrument Co. Ltd., People’ s Republic of China ), equipped with a UV3000 detector using a YMC-Pack ODS-A column (250 × 20 mm , 5 μm, Kyoto , Japan ). ODS (50 μ m, YMC, Japan ), and silica gel (200–300 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory, Qingdao, People’ s Republic of China ) were used for column chromatography. Silica gel GF 254 plates purchased from Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory (Qingdao, People’ s Republic of China ) were used for TLC analysis.

Rhizomes of
Iris domestica
L. ( Iridaceae ) [the name
Belamcanda chinensis
(L.) DC ( Iridaceae ) was recorded in Chinense Pharmacopoeia for 2020] were purchased from Anguo ( Hebei Province , P.R. China ) in September (autumn) 2017, and identified by Prof. Lin Ma ( Institute of Materia Medica ). A voucher specimen (S-2895) was deposited at Institute of Materia Medica , Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College
.
4.3. Extraction and isolation

The air-dried and powdered rhizomes of
I. domestica
( 50 kg ) were extracted with 95% ethanol (3 × 2 h × 120 L) to give 7.8 kg residues after evaporation under reduced pressure. The residue was successively partitioned with dichloromethane ( CH 2 Cl 2 ), ethyl acetate (EtOAc), and n -butanol ( n -BuOH). Iridal-type triterpenoids were mainly distributed in dichloromethane extract based on the TLC analysis. Subsequently, the CH 2 Cl 2 extract was chromatographed on a silica gel column and eluted with petroleum/acetone (10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, v/v) to obtain five fractions A-E. Fraction C was subjected to an ODS column and eluted with a gradient of MeOH–H 2 O of 65–100% to obtain eight fractions C-a to C-h. Fraction C-g was run on a silica gel column eluting with petroleum ether-ethyl acetate (20:1, 10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2) to obtain seven subfractions C-g-1 to C-g-7. C-g-3 was separated by preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O 75:25, 4 mL/min) to afford six subfractions: C-g-3-1 to C-g-3-6. C-g-3-3 was also fractioned by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 85:15, 4 mL/min) to obtain compounds 1 ( 4.2 mg ), 2 ( 6.8 mg ), and 6 (3.0 mg). Fraction C-g-3-4 was purified by preparative HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O 84:16, 4 mL/min) to afford compounds 3 ( 1.9 mg ), 4 ( 11.8 mg ), and 5 (10.0 mg).
4.3.1. Belamcandnoate A (1)

Pale yellow oil, [ α ] D 20 –82 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 267 (3.26), 342 (0.82) nm; IR u max 3224, 2925, 2861, 1736, 1635, 1452, 1075 cm 1 ; 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR data see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 703.33234 [M + H] + (calcd C 37 H 51 O 13 , 703.33242).
4.3.2. Belamcandnoate B (2)
4.3.3. Belamcandnoate C (3)
4.3.5. Belamcandnoate E (5)

sec.title: 4.4. Alkaline hydrolysis of 1–6
sec.p:
Compound 4 ( 2.4 mg ) was dissolved in CH 3 OH (3 mL), and excess NaOH aqueous solution (1 mol/L, 5 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The solution was acidified to a pH of 4 using 1 mol/L HCl and extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 . The CH 2 Cl 2 extract was analyzed by MS and two molecular formulas were probed: C 24 H 26 O 13 (M = 522) and C 18 H 32 O 2 (M = 280), which indicated that the chain length of fatty acid of 4 was C-18. Utilizing the same methods, alkaline hydrolysis products of compounds 1–3 , and 5–6 were detected by MS to determine that the carbon chain length of fatty acids were 14, 14, 16, 18 and 18, respectively. The structural elucidation of the glucoside moiety of 4 demonstrated that it shared the same structure with the known compound iridin. Iridin was obtained from the reaction mixture via preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O 30:70, 4 mL/min) (
).

sec.title: 4.5. Acidic hydrolysis of iridin, iristectorin A, tectoridin
4.6.1. Cytotoxic assay
sec.p: Cytotoxic activities of compounds 1–6 against HCT-116, HepG2, BGC-823, A549 and MCF-7 cells were measured by using the MTT method. Briefly, test cells in culture medium 100 μ L were seeded in each well of 96-well plates (Falcon, CA). Cells were treated in triplicate with 10 μ L of grade concentrations 0.1, 1, 10 μ M of the compounds at 37 ◦ C. After 72 h, a 20 μ L aliquot of MTT solution ( 5 mg /mL) was added to the wells. The cultures were incubated for another 4 h, and then 100 μ L of “triplex solution” (10% SDS/5% isobutanol/10 mM HCl) was added. The plates were incubated at 37 ◦ C in 5% CO 2 overnight. The OD values were measured at 570 nm by a plate reader (VERSA Max, Molecular Devices, Sunnyvale, CA). Average values determined from triplicate readings

were used for the inhibitory rate calculation by the formula: ( ODcontrol well – ODtreated well )/ ODcontrol well – ODblank well × 100%. The IC 50 was calculated using Logistic regression from three independent tests. Paclitaxel was used as the positive control with IC 50 values of 0.2, 10.69, 2.08, 2.68, 19 n M, respectively (
,b).

sec.title: 4.6.2. NO production bioassay
sec.p:
Compounds 1–6 were tested for their inhibitory effect on LPSinduced NO production in the BV2 cell line. The BV2 cells were plated in a 96-well plate and pretreated with the compounds for 24 h followed by an additional 24 h of LPS (0.3 μg/mL) exposure. The Griess reaction was used to determine the nitrite content in the culture supernatant. NaNO 2 served as a standard to assess the NO 2 concentration. The OD values were recorded at 550 nm . Curcumin was used as the positive control. Cell viability was measured by an MTT assay (
,b).

sec.title: 4.6.3. Antioxidant bioassays
